title: Definition drives design: Disability models and mechanisms of bias in AI technologies
authors: Denis Newman-Griffis, Jessica Sage Rauchberg, Rahaf Alharbi, Louise Hickman, Harry Hochheiser
keyAssumptions: AI bias emerges from algorithms; disability categories are objectively definable; technical solutions alone address bias
keyHypotheses: Bias emerges from fundamental design decisions about disability conceptualization; different disability models create different AI architectures
strengths: Novel framework linking disability models to AI design; comprehensive analysis of bias mechanisms
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation; primarily theoretical analysis
citation: Newman-Griffis, D., Rauchberg, J.S., Alharbi, R., Hickman, L., & Hochheiser, H. (2022). Definition drives design: Disability models and mechanisms of bias in AI technologies. arXiv:2206.08287
notes: Direct support for Assumption 4 - disability categories are dynamically constructed

title: Ethical Challenges of Germline Genetic Enhancement
authors: Ignacio Macpherson, María Victoria Roqué, Ignacio Segarra
keyAssumptions: Individual autonomy sufficient for genetic decisions; genetic modifications have predictable intergenerational effects
keyHypotheses: Germline modifications require new ethical frameworks beyond individual consent due to intergenerational impacts
strengths: Comprehensive ethical analysis; focuses on intergenerational impacts
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation of proposed frameworks
citation: Macpherson, I., Roqué, M.V., & Segarra, I. (2019). Ethical Challenges of Germline Genetic Enhancement. Frontiers in Genetics, 10, 767
notes: Direct support for Assumption 2 - individual autonomy insufficient for genetic selection decisions

title: Procreative Beneficence and Genetic Enhancement
keyAssumptions: Best possible life can be objectively determined; individual parental choice primary framework
keyHypotheses: Accepting procreative beneficence commits parents to genetic enhancement obligations
strengths: Clear logical argumentation; connects embryo selection to genetic modification
weaknesses: Purely philosophical analysis; no empirical testing of assumptions
citation: Veit, W. (2018). Procreative Beneficence and Genetic Enhancement. Kriterion - Journal of Philosophy, 32(1), 75-92
notes: Challenges Assumption 1 - questions objective determination of benefit/harm

title: Is a deaf future an Open future? Reconsidering the open future argument against deaf embryo selection
keyAssumptions: Deafness inherently limits opportunities; open future can be objectively defined; autonomy is individual
keyHypotheses: Open future arguments fail due to unjustified negative presumptions about deaf embodiments; autonomy has social/relational components
strengths: Challenges ableist assumptions; considers social construction of disability
weaknesses: Limited empirical testing of autonomy outcomes
citation: Tubig, P.A. (2023). Is a deaf future an 'Open' future? Reconsidering the open future argument against deaf embryo selection. Monash Bioethics Review, 41, 175-195
notes: Strong support for Assumption 4 - disability categories socially constructed rather than fixed medical conditions

title: Genetic Protection Modifications: Moving Beyond the Binary Distinction Between Therapy and Enhancement for Human Genome Editing
authors: Rasmus Bjerregaard Mikkelsen, Henriette Reventlow S. Frederiksen, Mickey Gjerris, Björn Holst, Poul Hyttel, Yonglun Luo, Kristine Freude, Peter Sandøe
keyAssumptions: Genetic interventions fit therapy/enhancement binary; ethical evaluation depends on categorization
keyHypotheses: Genetic protection modifications constitute third category for disease prevention interventions
strengths: Challenges binary thinking; provides specific medical examples
weaknesses: Limited empirical testing; no policy implementation validation
citation: Mikkelsen, R.B., Frederiksen, H.R.S., Gjerris, M., Holst, B., Hyttel, P., Luo, Y., Freude, K., & Sandøe, P. (2019). Genetic Protection Modifications: Moving Beyond the Binary Distinction Between Therapy and Enhancement for Human Genome Editing. CRISPR Journal, 2(6), 362-369
notes: Supports Assumption 1 challenge - genetic interventions exist on spectrums beyond traditional categories
